text: hi everyone thanks so much for having me
runner and for calling me magnificent my
name is Abby fuller I do DevOps at air
time and before I get a little bit into
what we've built with AWS a little bit
of background on what air time itself is
so air time is a new social experience
so we're trying to let your real friends
share real moments in real time through
group video messaging and more and I
think like pretty much any other app out
there it's a little easier if we can
demonstrate rather than just listen to
me talk so it can make you the first
video please cool so air time is
designed to be an intimate space so you
should be able to share your
conversations with your real friends in
real time so you can hit the signal
button which pulls your friends into the
room and then once you're there you can
chat with up to six people at once once
you're live you can do things like share
songs videos photos and see your friends
reaction to that in real time so you can
share a YouTube playlist your favorite
Spotify song clips from SoundCloud all
that great stuff and it should really
feel like you're hanging out in the
apartment with your friends so we have a
lot of features though and with a lot of
features can come a couple of challenges
and we've identified two of the big ones
that we think really impact us the most
and I think they probably apply to a lot
of you guys as well but that's speed and
scale so let's take a look at speed can
we cue the second video please awesome
so you can see our product vision here
so really fast really seamless messaging
and coke consumption of media so airtime
should feel like it's the next best
thing to hanging out with your friends
in real time so real life doesn't have
lag delays buffering those all interrupt
our product vision and they all
interrupt your airtime experience as
well so if I'm sitting on the couch with
my friend Nate and we're looking at
videos from a concert that we went to
last week there's no pause there and
there shouldn't be this whole delay
while I text and then wait and see if he
answers it when he's at work or not it
should really feel like we're hanging
out in real time and sharing that
experience rather than you know just
kind of going over it asynchronously
after the fact
cool so next up for us is scale speed
doesn't matter at all so you could have
the fastest app in the world if you can
only support
a couple of people at once so for us on
the AWS side this means that are all of
our infrastructure it needs to be multi
availability zone and it needs to be
multi region so we understand that your
friends and family aren't in one place
and air time should help you feel like
you're hanging out with them in real
life even when plane tickets are too
expensive like most other apps our
traffic also varies throughout the day
so we generally have up to ten times
more traffic at peak times then at slow
times so we need to scale back up and
then we're a small start-up so we don't
want to spend a ton of money so we want
to scale down really seamlessly to save
costs after the fact so a couple months
ago we took a hard look and said okay so
with speed and scale in mind what do we
have right now from an infrastructure
perspective and what do we not like
about it and we identified a couple of
main pain points for us so first off our
our application design as Vernor called
out is monolithic it was really hard to
rule changes and it was really hard to
optimize for performance we also had
bottleneck deployments so only a couple
people could deploy so I could be the
most productive developer in the whole
company and if I didn't have access to
deploy I had to still find a member of
the DevOps team we also found that that
monolith meant that a single issue could
cause system-wide failure which is
really hard to diagnose and finally we
had inconsistencies between our local
developer environments and staging and
production so these are all solvable
problems right so we took a big look at
this and said okay you know what
we're gonna rebuild the whole thing so
what do we actually want we have goals
so first user experience above all so
deployments should be zero downtime
servers should be redundant traffic
should be distributed we needed to set
ourselves up for scaling success so we
need to be able to scale intelligently
to support varying traffic and we need
to be able to balance requests between
our servers we needed cattle not pets so
some people have heard this before but
if I have a dog named Fido
I'm really attached but if I have a
whole herd of cattle I don't necessarily
know the name of each cow out there and
we felt the same way about servers so
they should be redundant and replaceable
not in phyto and replacing them should
be automatic and we need to develop our
efficiency so
tests and deployments should be seamless
and automatic and environments to be
consistent all the way from the first
developer vagrant environment up to
production and I will be the first
person to admit that these goals are not
particularly original they apply to
pretty much any company out there
whether you're a two-person startup
still or the biggest enterprise but we
wanted the best experience possible both
for our developers and for our end users
so we made this decision to overhaul and
from the beginning there's been a couple
of tenants that have been really kind of
stuck with us from the beginning and the
first is that we've always been on AWS
and we've always kept our core language
which is no js' the same and this has
led us keep our velocity really high
even though we have a really small
start-up team the biggest change that we
made though was obviously switching from
our old monolith to container based
micro services which in the airtime case
is docker on top of Amazon's ECS so why
containers and why CICS in the first
place so the big thing for us with
Amazon and I think with a lot of other
startups out there is the whole idea of
shared responsibility so we have a
really small team so what we can do is
we can share responsibility for Amazon
with some of our tasks so checking for
resource usage health checks monitoring
we trust that if we set things up
properly on our side and integrate
properly with AWS Amazon will tell us
that something's wrong and we can focus
on our product you also got the native
integration with other AWS products so
with ecs you get the native integration
with with load balancers from route 53
which meant that we could do things like
hit our zero downtime deployment goal
and rolling deployments by using some of
those features that were already baked
into load balancers and finally monolith
versus micro services is worth a whole
debate in and of itself but suffice to
say for us the big initial selling point
was that containers are atomic so we
could be consistent all the way from a
dev environment to production by boxing
all of our changes to these containers
so we could follow that same feature
that same change all the way from local
to production and that eliminates kind
of the whole argument of well this
worked locally and now production is on
fire so looking forward though
can't stop here so we're still a growing
startup and we need to solve new
challenges each and every day and one of
the ways that we're doing this is by
using more AWS products to help us grow
when we started using
ECS originally it was barely out of beta
and they add new future as almost as
quickly as we do we also need to keep
learning so as we learn more about our
growth and our users we still want to
keep speed and scale in mind so that we
can keep optimizing everything to
deliver the best possible experience so
finally working with AWS has let us put
more focus on building an awesome
product and less Sun worrying about our
infrastructure thank you
